Irvine, CA 1/5/2011 17 Check-ins Here A few years ago, if you had asked me what I thought about Chick-Fil-A's food, I would have told you I'd rather eat cardboard instead. Back then I thought the chicken sandwiches were bland, over-priced, and nothing to shout about.
Funny how my tastes have changed...guess I'm getting old!. The more time I spend eating here, the more I crave it. My favorite is the spicy chicken sandwich. Tender, juicy, meaty with a good amount of kick to it. I like to further up a notch by adding buffalo sauce to it. What's keeping me from coming back for more, more often? The prices. Hoooly crap does CFA know how to steal your $7.
But man, do they offer damn good food. Not just the sandwiches, but their milkshakes and ice "dreams" are so damn good, creamy, and smooth. My poor gut and wallet say no, but my taste buds say hell fuqing yes! And their sweet tea is good too. I don't even need to get started on the sauce offerings.
Add on top CFA's so-friendly-it's-creepy service from their so-friendly-it's-creepy staff (there's a reason for that), it all makes the CFA experience worthwhile.
And why you gotta close on Sundays?! (There's a reason for that...)
**TIP*** Sign up for their text message offers and you'll receive the occasional free food deals which is usually the draw to get me into the store. I'm a cheap bastard so this makes it more worth it to stop in.

Orange County, CA 12/4/2009 1 Check-in Here I've only tried Chick-Fil-A once before about two years ago in a mall food court somewhere in north NJ. I didn't think much of it at the time. Sure, it was fine. A decent chicken sandwich, nice waffle fries, nothing special. Nothing to get excited about.
So I sort of forgot about Chick-Fil-A even though they seem to be popping up all over the place lately. It just didn't entice me. Lately though I've been thinking about giving them another chance. What if the loud, crowded Jersey food court polluted my experience? What if they really were as good as everyone keeps saying? They deserve another chance. However, my husband was never too keen whenever I'd suggest it. If we're having a pig out drive thru session it's usually because one or both of us is craving grease. But tonight I ate solo and decided it was finally time to try them again.
I got a #2 chicken club combo. The sandwich looks fairly plain but it's actually very tasty. The chicken is thick and moist and has a lot of flavor. I like that you get a big leafy piece of lettuce, not watery iceberg. The waffle fries are also great. I like that this meal filled me up but didn't give me that disgustingly full just-ate-a-burger feeling.
Turned out it was some sort of promotional day or something because for the month of Dec if you take you receipt back next time you get the entire meal free!

Foothill Ranch, CA 3/14/2010 My favorite chicken sandwich is still the Chick-fil-a Original Sandwich. (McDonalds and KFC would call them crispy, a non-marketing person would call them Southern fried or deep fried). The seasoned crust holds together all the juices inside the chicken breast. Brownies ala mode highlight their unmatched vanilla soft serve ice cream. Less well known is the cheesecake, which is probably the richest, smoothest slice you can find anywhere. Breakfast is also good, but pricey. There is no animal style here, but the menu has far more healthier choices than In-N-Out: salads, wraps, and grilled chicken sandwiches.
Georgia's Chick fil A draws a lot of comparisons to California's In-N-Out. They are both Christian owned businesses (Chick Fil-A even closes on Sundays), managed by internally promoted employees (not rich franchisees who buy in), paying their employees well, delivering courteous service, and making above average food for slightly above average prices. In-N-Out is built on beef, and Chick-Fil-A is almost entirely chicken based. Both are carried on a highly devoted fan base.
Not everyone loves Chick-Fil-A. The "crispy" sandwiches occasionally get soggy in their foil wrappers, and the grilled sandwiches are honestly better at other places. The wraps and chicken salad sandwich are prepared way in advance, and as such, they are usually dry. If you want a chicken salad sandwich, Arby's across the street has a great one for about the same price.
I go to KFC for fried chicken, and I go to Chick-Fil-A for fried sandwiches and waffle fries. You can slightly off-set that Southern fried grease with sugarless beverages you can't easily find elsewhere: Diet Dr Pepper, Coke Zero, or their in-house Diet Lemonade. (for sour lovers only) Like In-N-Out, it's very popular, and the lines can get long. Parents, this location has an enclosed playground.
Where Chick-Fil-A always shines brightest is customer service. The operator of the store, himself a former associate from the South, spends every lunch picking up tables, talking with customers and working behind the counter. Every staff member is equally gracious and courteous. "My Pleasure" is the corporate catchphrase, and it always reminds you of that good food and Southern hospitality works in California just as well as it does in Georgia.

York, ME 6/4/2010 1 Check-in Here Superstar service. Some of the best customer service out there.
Normally I wouldn't write about a multi-state chain or a basic fast food place but the service alone is worth writing about. This is definitely a family place and a place that has company values. It completely shows. Definitely a refreshing to be in an establishment where the company values seem to be displayed genuinely and from bottom to top.
Everytime I have been in here, everyone is super-friendly, courteous, patient, and helpful. The one time the bf and I did not take our food to-go we happened to sit next to a table of elementary school-age girls who were sitting at a table different from their parents (it appeared that their parents were at the next table). An employee was going around checking on everyone making sure everyone was okay, making sure everyone's enjoying themselves. Now this lady assumed that the girls next to us were "our girls" and asked us if they needed anything and if we'd like her to get them more napkins, drinks, dipping sauces, etc. Whoa!!! We politely said "no" to the offer since those weren't our kids but wow, if they were, that is SUPER DUPER helpful!!! I can only imagine what it is like to have children but I can tell that if I did, an offer of help like that at any dining establishment must be such a huge lifesaver. Anyways, any place that is willing to offer that kind of assistance without be asked to in the first place is definitely in a league of its own in customer service.
The food is also really good. As many others have remarked, CFA is to chicken what In-N-Out is to beef. The quality and taste are elevated. I have quickly become a big fan of the nuggets, spicy crispy chicken sandwich and the lemon meringue pie.
Visit CFA if you're in the mood for a basic chicken sandwich and don't want to go to a scary and impersonal place like KFC.
One last tip, the company is fairly religious so CFA is closed on Sundays so keep that in mind if its Sunday and you're looking for some chicken!
